anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 12, 1961,
The appellant then asked for and obtained special leave-of this Court to appeal from the judgment
tried the appellant Prabhu on a charge of murdering his own uncle and found him guilty of the offence
hit by ss.25 and 26 of the Indian Evidence Act.

issues.text: whether the evidence given by the prosecution establishes beyond any reasonable doubt that the appellant was the murderer

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has taken us through the evidence in the case and has submitted that apart from raising some suspicion against the appellant and his father, the evidence given by the prosecution does number establish beyond any reasonable doubt that the appellant was the murderer.

issues.text: whether certain statements alleged to have been made by appellant to the Sub-Inspector of Police in connection with the recovery of the blood stained axe and blood stained shirt and dhoti were inadmissible and the courts below were wrong in relying on them

anchor.surface_text: He has further submitted that certain statements alleged to have been made by appellant to the Sub-Inspector of Police in connection with the recovery of the blood stained axe and blood stained shirt and dhoti were inadmissible and the courts below were wrong in relying on them. He has contended that if those statements are excluded from consideration, than the evidence which remains is insufficient to support the conviction of the appellant,

issues.text: whether the statement that the axe was one with which the murder had been committed or that the blood stained shirt and dhoti belonged to the appellant led to any discovery within the meaning of s.27 of the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: These statements to which Dobi Baksh P.W.3 deposed were number admissible in evidence. They were incriminating statements made to a police officer and were hit by ss.25 and 26 of the Indian Evidence Act. The statement that the axe was one with which the murder had been committed was number a statement which led to any discovery within the meaning of s.27 of the Evidence Act.

issues.text: Is the production of the blood stained axe and clothes read in the light of the evidence regarding motive sufficient to lead to the conclusion that the appellant must be the murderer

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution gave numberevidence to establish whether the axe belonged to the appellant or the blood stained clothes were his. Therefore, the question before us is this. Is the production of the blood stained axe and clothes read in the light of the evidence regarding motive sufficient to lead to the conclusion that the appellant must be the murderer ?

issues.text: whether the evidence as to motive is satisfactory

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the evidence as to motive is satisfactory, Both Naiku P.W.1 and Brij Lal P.W.2 have stated about the motive. The appellant and his mother stayed with Bhagwan about four years ago in order to render assistance to Bhagwan in his cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: Nor was the alleged statement of the appellant that the blood stained shirt and dhoti belonged to him was a statement which led to any discovery within the meaning of s.27.

arguments.claim: true interpretation of s.27 per Pulukuri Kotayya: fact discovered embraces place and knowledge of accused; info must relate distinctly; past user/history inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: Section 27 provides that when any fact is deposed to and discovered in companysequence of information received from a person accused of any offence, in the custody of a police officer,-so much of such information,.whether it amounts to a companyfession or number, as, relates distinctly to the fact thereby discovery may be proved. In Pulukuri Kotayya v. King Emperor  1  the Privy Council companysidered the true interpretation of s.27 and said It is fallacious to treat the fact discove- red within the section as equivalent to the object produced the fact discovered embraces the place from which the object is produced and the knowledge of the accused as to this, and the information given must relate distinc- tly to this fact. Information as to past user, or the past history, of the object produced is number related to its discovery in the setting in which it is discovered.

arguments.claim: courts below were wrong in admitting the alleged statements that axe used for murder or clothes his

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the companyrts below were wrong in admitting in evidence the alleged statement of the appellant that the axe had been used to companymit murder or the statement that the blood  1   1947  L.R. 74 I.A 65. stained shirt and dhoti were his.

arguments.claim: production of blood stained axe and clothes with motive insufficient to conclude appellant murderer; circumstantial evidence must lead to conclusion consistent only with guilt

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that circumstantial evidence must be much as to lead to a companyclusion which on any reasonable hypothesis in companysistent only with the guilt of the accused person and number with his innocence.

anchor.surface_text: We think that these contentions are correct and must be upheld. There can be no doubt that Bhagwan was murdered on the night in question. The postmortem examination disclosed that he had sustained as many as thirteen injuries,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council in Pulukuri Kotayya limiting s.27 to info distinctly relating to place and knowledge of object, excluding past use

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statements violate ss.25,26 and do not qualify under s.27 exception

holdings.text: circumstantial evidence must be such as to lead to a conclusion which on any reasonable hypothesis is inconsistent only with the guilt of the accused person and not with his innocence

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that circumstantial evidence must be such as to lead to a conclusion which on any reasonable hypothesis is inconsistent only with the guilt of the accused person and not with his innocence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled standard requires complete chain excluding innocence hypothesis

anchor.surface_text: In Pulukuri Kotayya v. King Emperor 1 the Privy Council companysidered the true interpretation of s.27 and said It is fallacious to treat the fact discove- red within the section as equivalent to the object produced the fact discovered embraces the place from which the object is produced and the knowledge of the accused as to this, and the information given must relate distinc- tly to this fact.

precedents.cited_proposition: True interpretation of section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act: only information relating distinctly to the place of discovery and accused's knowledge of it is admissible; information about past use or history of the object is not.
precedents.cited_holding: It is fallacious to treat the fact discovered within the section as equivalent to the object produced... if to the statement the words be added with which I stabbed A., these words are inadmissible since they do not relate to the discovery of the knife in the house of the informant.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the respondent has submitted to us that in State of U. P. v. Deoman Upadhyaya 1 this Court accepted as sufficient evidence the production of a blood stained weapon. We are unable to agree. The circumstantial chain in that case did number depend merely on the production of the gandasa, but on other circumstance as well.

precedents.case_name: State of UP v Deoman Upadhyaya
precedents.cited_proposition: Production of a blood stained weapon can be sufficient evidence in a circumstantial case.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that circumstantial evidence must be such as to lead to a conclusion which on any reasonable hypothesis is inconsistent only with the guilt of the accused person and not with his innocence.
For the reasons given above we would allow the appeal and set aside the companyviction and sentence passed against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution gave no evidence to establish whether the axe belonged to the appellant or the blood stained clothes were his. Therefore, the question before us is this. Is the production of the blood stained axe and clothes read in the light of the evidence regarding motive sufficient to lead to the conclusion that the appellant must be the murderer ?
